bibl.title: Letter from Paul de Kruif to J. F. Siler, June 23 1927

div1.p: De Kruif informs Siler of a play about the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Paul de Kruif to J. F. Siler, June 23 1927

opener.dateline:
830 Bronx River Road
Bronxville--New York
June 23 1927

div1.p:
Thanks for your information: it was just
what we wanted. It is very important for us that Reed apparent-
ly did not issue an order or any formal call for volunteers, but
that he had the wisdom instead to get his men through sergeants
and by personal communication.

Is it too much to ask General Hugh Scott's
rank at the time he was adjutant to Wood, October, 1900,? May-
be I ought to know this. Undoubtedly he was a major?

Thanks too for your kindness in placing
meetings with Mrs. Reed and General Kean within our reach. Howard
is now up at Wiscasset, Maine; he leaves for England August 1st.
I shove off tomorrow for Blue Water, our summer place on the
Lake Michigan shore. Howard and I meet again in the autumn, mid-
September, just before the play goes into rehearsal. It will not
be put on until November at the earliest. We will be down to
see you before that.

Howard is doing a mag-
nificent job on the dramatization. We went over the first five
scenes last Sunday. The meeting of Reed and Finlay and the death
of Lazear actually drew a little tear to my eye. He has finished
the last scene, too---which represents Walter Reed, writing the
famous New Year's eve letter to his wife, and the curtain goes
down on the blowing of taps for the new year.

My Michigan address is R.R.# 6, Holland
Michigan.
